description:
I happened to be in town for one of my best friend's weddings and my other friend and I decided to stop by and try some ramen on the way to a picnic (like a true foodie.. stopping for food before eating more food). 

My girl was craving ramen and I am ALWAYS down for some ramen. The weather was cool and I had driven my pup along with us so we picked this place because of proximity, outdoor seating (dog friendly!), and of course, a high rating on yelp. 

Decor is modern with their menu plastered on the wall. Realistically, I only caught a glimpse of the inside, but the outdoor seating is really cute with hanging lightbulbs and plenty of room for pups. 

The server loved dogs so she was so friendly and accommodating for us. We each ordered the same thing: spicy tonkatsu ramen with crispy garlic and a side of edamame to share. 

It was DELICIOUS! The flavors were different than what I'm used to in SoCal, but it was still such a savory, umami filled bowl of ramen! I ordered the pork belly meat and that was literally falling apart, it was so tender! The garlic added that perfect seasoning! I usually order edamame when I know the meal can be a bit meat heavy and it was a nice thing to munch on between bites of the soup. 

Overall, I truly enjoyed this place and will plan to come back my next visit to SF!
author: Ailleen J.

description:
Cons:  
Broth needs fat or collagen. My broth had so little body! 
Noodles - nothing noteworthy. 

Pros:  
The toppings were fresh and well balanced. 
I felt the egg was appropriate in size and texture. 
The chashu was perfectly tender.
And unlike other reviewers my request for extra spice was honored with extra spice. 

Worthwhile if you're in the area but, not a ramen I'd brave an extended trip of MUNI weirdos for. Solid middle of the road to slightly better option. I'd go 3.5 if Yelp let me do half stars.
author: Liss T.

description:
First, it's no longer a food truck. It's nothing closer to any real Ramen noodle shop except the name of the place. The food is edible and at the level of a school cafeteria. 

For the rest : 1) the noodle is obviously from a package 2) the soup base is from boxed miso block 3) no ginger, no side dishes to clear your taste buds. 4) soft boiled eggs are way below market standard- don't expect anything that looks like the photo on the menu. 

If you have ever been to any ramen place in Japan town or in Japan, you will know the difference right away. It shouldn't be called " Ramen shop", it's just a noodle shop.
author: Anny Z.

description:
Wasnt entirely exactly how i remembered it from when they were at soma streats. I was excited they had their store front because i remembered loving it!

I had to come in and reminisce. Its self serve and orderimg is easy. Dont worry if theres a line, it moves fast. What i observed its a chinese japanese fusion ramen.

Ordered tonkotsu pork belly with garlic spicy. They ran out of black garlic. I wasnt impressed at all with the broth. The belly was on point though. Price wasnt bad and portions were awesome.

Bf had the miso. It was much better. And i never like the miso.

Tried chicken wing. Nice and fatty from skin and pretty much boneless.

I would go somewhere else for my ramen as there are so many places in the city. Didnt meet my ramen crave
author: Lynn C.

description:
I like ramen places like here in which you order and then sit, there's not many of them. It's very red inside, plenty of seating, staff there was little interaction. But the order came out in a reasonable amount of time. The menu is not big, it's a few ramen items plus some side dishes. I like that there's more than 1 vegetarian item on the menu.

I got the vegan miso ramen, which actually does have a flavorful vegan broth, something that other places find hard to do. It comes with a soy product, tofu, seaweed, green onion, and bamboo. The noodles are cooked well, I'm not sure if they're egg-free but that's fine for me.

Overall, this is a good try in the area. It's a little on the pricey side for ramen, but it's made well and is a decent portion with the right amount of toppings.
author: Spencer H.

description: Cute place. Decent food. For some reason the ramen seemed a bit too complex from what I'm used to as far as broth and the beef donburi was actually seasoned just right and not too sweet like most other places so it evened out. Good service, good prices and quick to serve.
author: Guisela L.

description:
Delish. Called-in a takeout order on a Saturday afternoon at 2pm. Estimated wait time, five minutes.

Had the Vegan miso ramen with: corn, bean sprout, fungus, tofu and grilled garlic. Medium heat. Really tasty, one order is enough for two, noodle is chewy and delicious, pretty good amount of heat, and the flavor and scent are slightly reminiscent of pizza. 

Overall, hit the spot, it's comfort food.

Can't wait to order again!
author: Elizabeth T.

description: Let me say first that I eat a lot of ramen. I travel the world for a living and haven consumed a great deal of ramen throughout Japan. This is not ramen. There is almost a tomato soup taste to the broth. When I ordered extra spice, there was literally no spice added to the bowl, and yet they charged an additional dollar for the spice (which they never told me about when I ordered, nor is it listed as such in the menu). Total jive. I was full and walked away not feeling terrible but I definitely felt cheated. This review is in hopes that the Thai proprietors will learn that a good bowl of ramen is an art and not just a trendy food that they can upsell 1.50 for additional corn and other extras. Also in hopes that someone like me will see this and choose to go elsewhere.
author: Mikey W.

description: Flavorful ramen and fast service. The pork belly is really sweet, so if you are into that, then you will really like it. Prices are average, given the area. It can get super busy during lunch, so expect a wait time if you go around that time.
author: Alejandra A.

description: I've eaten here twice and my conclusion is that the food here is just not that good. Bland, soggy, uniformly. No excuses! There are so many good ramen places in San Francisco. Izakaya Goku for one, which is not that far from this place. However I live near Torraku and so I have a vested interest in having a better ramen place in my neighborhood. Time for this place to make room for something better.
author: Jesse G.

description: My daughters new favorite restaurant! We came here after having dessert first over at Milkbomb Ice Cream around the corner. The vegan ramen was bomb and the kids loved the chicken katsu. Service is very friendly and I love how they take the time to box up your leftovers! They have a restroom nextdoor and it's pretty clean even close to closing time. Big plus in my book. Atmosphere is nice and chill. Definitely coming back!
author: Rori V.

description:
I seriously want to consider moving to San Fran just so I can eat this ramen regularly. It is so. so. so. so. good.

I had the curry ramen, which I was curious about, unsure what to expect. It was brilliant--the curry taste for sure present, but not overwhelming. I loved loved LOVED the broth; it also wasn't ridiculously over-salty, which is so satisfying. The noodles were the perfect firmness and the chashu meat was so flavorful. I don't love eggs, but ohmygoodness the egg in the ramen is cooked (err, soft boiled) to absolute perfection... it is magical. Savor. It. I also got an add-in of fungi: would recommend!

Noon rush: a real thing! the line can get long, but don't be intimidated... it moves pretty quickly. just know it happens. this place is for sure worth any wait.
author: Irina H.

description:
I met up with a friend who worked at Adobe to try out this ramen place down the street. It didn't feel too crowded at lunch. No lines though we took a while to make up our minds. We both ordered the tonkatsu ramen - me with pork belly and she with chasu pork. The ramen came out farily quickly. I enjoyed my pork belly tonkatsu ramen, no spice level. She didn't like the chasu pork - said the pork belly was much better. But we both liked the noodles and broth.

Pretty solid contender in the ramen space. Especially in the ramen-for-lunch and not the ramen-needs-to-blow-my-mind category. C'mon peeps. Ramen is ramen. No need to make this a life-altering event.

Luckily they have a permanent-ish location on De Haro so enough with hunting down the truck.
author: Jean K.

description: I had the seafood Yaki Soba and my daughter had the Don Buri and both were very delicious!. The serving of Don Buri was large that it could feed 2 adults.  My Yaki Soba was also a lit, it was soo good i ate the whole thing. I should have stopped half way. Will return and try other items on the menu.
author: Elaine T.

description: Ramen was good, they made an effort to make thier food work for people with allergies also.
author: Michael E.

description:
3.5 stars. This establishment is no longer a food truck. 

We arrived for a late lunch on a weekday afternoon. I ordered the tonkatsu with chasu and he ordered the miso with kakuni. The tonkatsu broth was very flavorful and the noodles were well cooked. Comparing the chasu and kakuni- both were pretty good. If you're not a fan of pork fat, definitely stick with the chasu. It was tender and not at all dry. For the kakuni, I always feel like I'm digging for meat hidden in the fat. Anyway, his choice; not mine. 

Why the 3.5? Well, although the ramen was good, it wasn't exactly memorable nor had a wow factor that I typically look for when I eat. I like to leave establishments with a strong urge to return in the near future.. I did not have this feeling after my meal here. Overall, it's an OK place, but there is definitely better ramen elsewhere in the city.
author: Leslie C.

description: Came here back in Jan. right after it opened. Service was okay but the broth was just off.
author: Berlin B.

description: Vegetarian, veggie and vegan options in ramen are available here. I got a veggie ramen to-go. Fried garlic adds great flavor to the broth. Will be back soon to try the vegan option.
author: Ramya T.

description: Not that exciting, not a fan of joints that don't disclose if chicken for example is antibiotic free etc. That said, my dish was fresh & tasted good.
author: Henry K.

description: Well priced food with great taste. Usually never a line since it's still new. Good amount of meat, noodles and broth!
author: Adé F.

description:
From all the reviews and the different medias, I really wanted to love this place, but it was average and mostly forgettable. I went to the food truck in SOMA StrEat Food Park.

While you stand in line, grab a menu and a pencil and start filling in what you want. It makes it less confusing for the guy at the window. If you want to look at what you're ordering, the truck also has pictures on the side. 

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with black garlic. It comes with a pork-chicken soup base, chashu, half soft boiled egg, fungus, bamboo, and green onions. The soup base was very weak. it wasn't creamy and reminded me of chicken stock that needed more simmer. The added black garlic made the whole base also taste weirdly burnt/salty and overpowering. The flavors reminded me of the Nissin Black Garlic Oil Instant Ramen Noodles. The noodles were cooked okay and the egg was good, but for the price point, $15+ you can head to Japantown and have a bigger bowl with more flavor.
author: Junella T.

description: Finally: a good ramen restaurant in a neighborhood filled with lots of other ethnic cuisines.  Torraku gives you the traditional broth choices, and the portions are large and filling.  They're fast, and perfect for calling ahead to pick up later.
author: Carlo A.

description:
Mexican, ramen, pizza, empanadas... I truly LOVE them all. That makes SoMa StrEat Food Park a very difficult place to dine, because how can you pick just one?!

On this particular evening, I had the weather and my flailing immune system to help me decide. It was cold, I happened to have a cold, so ramen seemed like the most logical and tempting dinner choice.

I followed the instructions on the side of the truck, grabbing the paper to designate what I wanted. My ramen knowledge is growing by the month, but I'm still no expert. Knowing that I am a fan of tonkotsu which is a rich pork broth, I got that with chasu. In other words, pork on pork! I decided not to add garlic of any sort which I now realized would've helped my cold but alas... I did get it at a medium level of spice which was perfect, and didn't go for any other extras. It was all ready for me to slurp down in about seven minutes!

The broth was some of the most flavorful I've had. There was a solid amount of chasu, as well as extras like bamboo shoots and, of course, noodles. I was left feeling full and satisfied with even a little left in the bowl. If you can tolerate spice, I would recommend getting it medium level or higher. It was delicious! 

I would definitely recommend this truck to anyone looking for restaurant quality ramen from a food truck. Sick or not!
author: Cassie P.

description:
Found this truck at the SOMA Streatfood Park the other day and I've wanted to try this truck for quite some time.  After reviewing the menu, I decided upon the Tonkotsu Kakuni Ramen and ordered it medium spicy.  

I took my lunch back to work and I like that they divided my order into two containers.  One was for the broth, while the other contained the noodles, Kakuni, green onions, egg and nori.  This allows everything to stay fresh and not allow the noodles to over-saturate within the broth.
I enjoyed the Tonkotsu broth and the spiciness was just right.  It had a bit of a kick, but wasn't too spicy so I was able to enjoy the flavor of the broth.  I enjoyed my ramen and the Kakuni was tender and had good flavor.  The noodles were cooked just right as well.

However, I feel it's a bit overpriced, considering I can get comparable ramen for less.  I also feel you should get more for what you're paying for.  This was a nice option on a cold SF morning.
author: Lon H.

description:
A ramen place in SF where we parked in a lot out front, walked in with a party of four, immediately ordered, and then sat down with no wait at 7pm on a Saturday night? Amazing!

The food here was fantastic, but I think the fact that we didn't have to wait on a Saturday night was even nicer. I ordered the miso chashu ramen, and it was great. Everyone in our party was also happy with their food. You can order bottles of sake up front!

Will be coming back!
author: Brian M.

description:
I've had a fair bit of ramen and this is one of my favorite ramen joints in San Francisco. Noodles are the right texture. Clean tasty and properly spiced broth. I had vegan + black garlic + spicy. 

Excellent overall!
author: Bowen D.

description:
At Sparks for a work thing, my co-worker got the Tonkotsu Ramen, which was really good. It was a warmer day, so I went with poki, but the broth was deep and rich. It was not too salty and I would prefer it a little spicier, but my co-worker does not handle spicy well, so for a non spicy Tonkotsu Ramen, it was very good. The meat was a little fatter then I like, but was very happy with the taste. Ramen egg was perfect, not overcook.

I would go back again, but wish the truck as at other locations in SF or east bay.
author: Mei L.

description:
Love this place. Super friendly staff, very clean, not taking any shortcuts. Parking right in front of the door and next to the police station. 

Food came quickly, just the right level of spiciness, broth superb, ingredients fresh, all made right here.

Wonderful addition to the neighborhood, highly recommended.
author: M K.

description:
I had the vegetarian version and it was good!   I asked for 2nds.

For Eco reasons, I wonder can we bring our own bowls when ordering.  I just don't want to use the black plastic bowls
author: Sunny O.

description:
Highlights
- A good ramen restaurant in the hood without the crazy lines. THIS is what I've been anticipating since I've tried their truck at Spark Social and saw the coming soon sign!
- Every bowl of ramen is customizable. Pick up a piece of paper, a pencil, mark-up selections to your heart's desire, and get in line to pay. Self serve water, utensils, and open seating.
- Tonkatsu ramen with Kakuni (braised pork belly) is the way to go. The kakuni is so flavorful, fatty, and tender. EVERY bowl of ramen needs this. Reminds me of comfort food on a cold winter day. 
- Indoor seating or outdoor patio seating for pet owners, love!

Improvements
- Outdoor seating is a bit chilly, but perfect once the pipping hot bowl of ramen comes out and perfect if you have a dog. 

Tips
- Not crowded, but limited seating so might not be a the best for a huge group. Plenty of free residential parking.
author: Tracy T.

description:
TL;DR: The ramen here is good. It's a solid 3-star joint. If I was being a creep I'd give it two stars because it's not worth $20 for the basic bowl I got and a can of Coke.  I wouldn't say "no" to if my colleagues wanted to go there, but it wouldn't be my first suggestion.  

(Now for the "TL") It was good. I wasn't unhappy eating it. I got shoyu with pork shoulder. It was shoyu broth. It had pork shoulder. I ate it. It was good. I'm struggling to think of what more to say. The can of Coke was fresh. I drank it. Um... I paid $20 for a $12 bowl + Coke. Maybe it was an $8 12oz can of Coke? Uh... My tummy was full? Yes.
author: Jason G.

description:
Torraku has gone brick and mortar in a spot where restaurants fail but if anyone can make a go of the space they can. The space has been home to everything from French, Brazilian, American and I think even Italian in the last 15 years. With no foot traffic at night it's hard to get walk-ins. However everyone loves ramen and Torraku makes sure they have some thing for everyone with two vegan choices, one vegetarian, a seafood ramen and all the usual ramen with pork. The prices are reasonable with everything under $14 and all the carnivore ones come already with eggs, you can get additional servings of things but it's not like they nickel and dime you for the ingredients like other hipster ramen places.

You order on an order form and pay at the cashier. Currently they are understaffed and the cashier was also delivering the food to the tables as well as instructing the kitchen staff. They are looking for a counter person and I hope that it happens soon.

Secondly this is Chinese style ramen where they make it spicy to cover up the broth that's lacking the depth of flavour. It's still good just not that richness that the broth should be. It's still more flavourful than many hipster ramen places. They also have gyoza and other dishes.

it's busy at lunch with the assorted techies but quiet at night so far. Space is wheelchair accessible but they have set up the order area and que in such a way that makes it a tight turning radius. They keep all the decor pretty much the same as the Brazilian space.
author: DeathandFood H.

description: I ordered delivery. Got the tonkotsu-not spicy and the miso ramen-mild. The miso ramen broth was not close to mild. I should have not even tried it, because the broth looked red. Besides being overly spicy for mild, the broth tasted like grease. The tonkotsu both was strangely sweet, and not a rich broth like I'm used to for tonkotsu. The noodles were cooked ok. The pork belly wasn't very good. It seemed edible, I was hungry so I ate it. Then I felt very sick about 10 minutes after eating and felt that way all night.
author: Nicole M.

description:
I've eaten twice at this food truck (well three times if you count the time I went for seconds at our company outing). It's hard to believe that ramen can be churned out in a food truck without any loss of quality. Both the braised pork and chasu options are delicious. I prefer the Tonkatsu ramen because the broth is more rich and I usually get it with black garlic oil. Extra spicy is a $1 more (bring your own ghost chili). Extra noodles is $2 more and highly recommended. Just make sure you arrive hungry. I also ordered edamamme for $3 and it comes in a box. The pictures on the menu are accurate so if you're looking to see what's in your ramen, take a moment and then fill out their form to order. They take credit cards so that's always a plus in my book. 

Total damage was $19 which is more than I would spend at Ramen Dojo but they are much closer to my house and there's no crazy line out the door.
author: Tim G.

description: They told me would take 10 minutes to make my food and it took them a half an hour very upset
author: Calum W.

description: I've only been to the food truck and it always hits the spot. Probably the best ramen in Mission Bay area. The wait time isn't too long and the staff is friendly.
author: Ashley N.

description:
Went to the food truck park for lunch and had a good experience at Torraku. I ordered tonkatsu ramen and it was satisfying. My favorites parts of the noodle bowl are the chashu and soft-boiled eggs. The are both well-cooked with balanced amount of marination. The soup is not very thick and could be improved. I also wish the ramen could be more chewy. The server is very nice. Overall a good choice for a quick lunch bite. 

Sustainability comments: great job using molded fiber bowls instead of plastics! I'd love to see an option for reusable chopsticks.
author: Lynn S.

description:
this is for the brick and mortar location on deharo, not the food truck at spark. 

perfectly serviceable ramen joint with really good tempura(!!!). really unique vegan chashu option available too. 

one suggestion: let us fill out the customization forms so we know what we can do to the ramen ourselves. husband and I would have preferred to add or subtract a few things but weren't able because the cashier asked us questions and filled out the forms for us.
author: Archana P.

description: We dropped into this place by accident tonight and would be happy to eat here again. I tried the tonkastsu ramen with the pork belly and pork shoulder and the better half tried the yakisoba. We split some chicken karage. The ramen was flavorful and the portions were large and filling. The place was spotlessly clean, the service was very friendly and our orders came out quickly. I chatted with the manager for a few minutes on our way out. The have a pretty busy lunch business, but things are quieter in the evening when we went... so if you want to get into a ramen place without having to wait, this place would be a great option. Two mains, an app and two glasses of wine for under $60.
author: Richard F.

description:
Wow the first veggie ramen I actually liked 
Good options 
Not too expensive 
Can sit inside or out
author: David G.

description:
Japanese ramen from a truck, bound to happen sooner or later although I heard it's very challenging to pursue (see JapaCurry). So props to this hardworking team for making it a reality!

For $12 a bowl, you can choose from a variety of broths but I stuck with the traditional tonkotsu pork bone broth, pairing it with kakuni (braised) fatty pork. While the bowl had a light to medium texture to it, I thought it could use more time developing the broth by cooking the bones longer and having a creamier texture.

Toppings were standard, a few bamboo shoots, seaweed, half a runny egg, three pieces of delicious pork, woodear mushroom, and some green onion. Lots of noodles, which weren't particularly notable since I don't think these are home made. While the ramen noodles were chewy, they could have more texture to them and felt fairly off the shelf.

All in all, it's great to have a ramen option available via food truck format, but I might not have the same excitement as I did the first time around.
author: Steven C.

description: Just left dinner here and really liked it! It's nice to have a ramen place that serves tonkotsu ramen close to home. We've had a hard time finding good versions of it (as opposed to shoyu) nearby. Tastes different than Ippudo but great! You can adjust the spice levels, add toppings, do different types of garlic. They also offer both chashu and pork belly as options. They've also got beer, wine, sake, and pop. Easy parking and was able to get seated easily. If this place did delivery through one of those delivery apps, I would be so so into it.
author: M N.

description:
I was a little hesitant to try food truck ramen, but mmm Torraku Ramen definitely went above expectations! I got the shoyu ramen with kakuni, medium spicy, no garlic (after the Gilroy garlic festival last year I really can't handle too much garlic...)

Broth - My first impression of the broth was the little circles of oil floating near the top, but it was surprisingly not too oily or greasy. It was hot, tasty and good for chasing down large mouthfuls of noodles.

Noodles - I thought the noodles were pretty great, as they were firm and had a good bite. Just what I like from my ramen noodles!

Toppings - highlights here were definitely the egg and kakuni. They both had this rich, sweet flavor that went well with the salty shoyu. The egg was creamy, with the yolk slightly cooked on the outside but soft and a little runny on the inside. I was surprised that the texture held in the food truck! The pork was pretty fatty and a little dry, but the meat was so flavorful, and I was given 4 good-sized pieces, more than I usually expect in a bowl of ramen. The soft flakiness of the pork melted around the noodles, creating a perfect texture in every bite. The bamboo was good as well, but there were only three pieces - a little lacking. 

Service was also really quick (~5 min). A tip is to fill out the paper order form, which we didn't immediately notice. That way you don't have to remember to list all your order details. Also, note that it's $12/bowl, and customized toppings can be $2-$3 each. It's a little pricey, but it's also San Francisco and a food truck, so higher prices are somewhat expected.
author: Hali M.

description:
I love this place!! . I started going to their food truck in SOMA Streat Park a few years back and now I make the walk to their new restaurant. I'm proud of them, they deserve it! Nice family. 

Price: a bit pricey but I rather spend an extra few bucks and have it go to a family owned business. 

Vegan/Veggie options: I've only had the vegan ramen, but it's the best I've had. Add black garlic! You won't be disappointed.

Noon rush: try to avoid or be prepared. Service is quick but the line gets long and goes out the door. If you're lucky you can get a spot on the cute patio. Heat lamps too!

Service: very friendly. People complain about having to buss your own table. This is a busy area for people on their lunch break and this place gets packed very quickly. It's nice to go when you need to go. They don't have refillable drinks, so what kind of service are you really expecting? Get a grip.
author: Vee S.

description:
I ended up here randomly, it looks new. You have to order on a checklist and bus your own table. Looking at the characters on the menu, and judging by the taste of the broth and noodles it is more a Chinese or Taiwanese noodle soup with all the toppings typically found in traditional ramen. 

That being said it wasn't all that bad, the broth and noodles were good and it was a just-right portion. I got the tonkatsu ramen which was appropriately rich but the chashu was cold :(

Offers gluten free video and vegetarian and vegan options if you roll like that.  It's a little pricey for the fact that they make you bus your own table and overall quality.
author: Alicia T.

description:
I don't understand how some restaurants can't get Ramen right but a food truck can knock it out of the park {literally, they're knocking it out of the Soma StEat Food PARK!}. If you enjoy Ramen, you should definitely make a stop by this food truck and grab a bowl to share. I recommend the Tonkotsu Ramen with a chicken/pork based broth thats been boiling for fifteen hours, it just gets better from their. Add the meats: chashu (pork) or kakuni (pork belly) and topped with half a soft boiled egg, mushrooms, bamboo and green onions. They also let you add your choice of fried or black garlic and mildly spicy to extra spicy flavor. 

If you've got to have ramen, this is a great option, although if you're trying to decide which food truck to visit at Soma, I would rank this as a tie for third place with Curry Up Now after No No Burger and Odang Udon.
author: Rose L.

description:
It's not surprise that SF has some killer ramen places. Especially at the outdoor food-truck parks around the city. The air is brisk and ramen broth warms you up from your core. It's the perfect cold weather, feel good food. 

Torraku Ramen is a food truck at SoMa StrEat Food Park. When I went, they were nestled in the back corner and I might have missed out if someone hadn't suggested it. Someone else suggested which ramen to get, I guess I wasn't in a decision making mood. It all worked out for the best though. 

I had the Miso, with Pork Belly, Medium Spice-Level, plus Black Garlic. Whew, that's a mouth full -- but so was the food. The black garlic really made the dish different and unique (sometimes ramen gets redundant). They cook it for 15 hours, so it better be good by then. 

You can't really go wrong at this place, unless you skip the black garlic.
author: Luci H.

description:
3.5 STARS

Yesterday, I had a hankering for ramen and have been wanting to try Torraku Ramen at SoMa StrEat Food Park. Thinking that it wouldn't be crowded on a weekday and parking would be a breeze, I drove down there. When I arrived, there was zero parking. Apparently, people that work in the area park in the area all day since there's a lot of non-metered parking. After circling 5-6 times, I stalked this guy who left the food park. Yes - rock star parking in front! He took what seems like eternity adjusting his mirrors before finally putting his seat belt on. He turns on his car, turns it off, gets out of the car and walks across the street. The inconsiderate phucktard could of told me he was NOT leaving when he initially got into his car since he saw me waiting for his space. *shakes fist* 

After circling another 4 rounds, I found metered parking around the block. I stepped out of the car and onto fresh, dinosaur-size turds. Lovely. 

As I was waiting in line to place my order at Torraku Ramen, Tater Tot decided to lay down in a puddle of water. Brown, muddy water at that. 

Sometimes you have to laugh this sh*t off. Literally.

Torraku Ramen serves up 6 kinds of ramen: Seafood, Tonkotsu, Shoyu, Miso, Curry, and Veggie. They're all $12 a bowl except for the seafood ramen ($13). For the tonkotsu, shoyu, miso, and curry ramen, you have a choice of Kakuni (pork belly) or Chashu (pork shoulder). You have an option to add garlic and choose your level of spiciness. Except for the seafood ramen, all bowls come with half an ajitsuke tamago, bamboo shoots, wood ear mushrooms, pickled ginger, scallions, and nori. Extra toppings (corn, cabbage, bamboo, bean sprouts) are an additional $1. NO msg is used which is a huge plus! You can order to go for an extra 10 cents (also offers delivery through GrubHub). IMO, just like a Neapolitan pizza, you shouldn't order ramen to go; the quality will not be the same as if you eat it on the spot.  

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen w/ kakuni, wood ear mushrooms, bamboo shoots, ajitsuke tamago, nori, medium spicy ($12). I also added black garlic ($1) and corn ($1): http://bit.ly/1nzVdoz. With a bottle of water (Voss only) and tip, my total was over $21; kinda pricey. 

My order was ready in about 5 minutes and was piping hot. Everything was on-point except the broth. I highly suggest ordering the ramen "no spicy" because the chili oil was so overpowering that you couldn't taste the rich milkiness of the tonkotsu broth (if there was any). All I tasted was oil so I didn't drink much of the broth. The noodles were al-dente and springy with a good chew. The kakuni had a higher fat ratio to meat then I would have preferred but it was flavorful and tender. The highlight was the ajitsuke tamago, marinated soft boiled egg. The soy marinade produced a savory sweetness and the egg had a beautiful molten center. The portion was filling. I'm very intolerant to msg and had zero issues afterwards - so they really don't use it. 

As I was slurping my ramen, a guy sat next to me with his order from Bacon Bacon. We said, hi to each other and he started taking obligatory food pics. I was always taught not to stare but I couldn't stop staring at him from the corner of my eye...

He was videotaping himself eating his burger and fries with commentary and all. Is this some new trend that I'm not aware of?

P.S. - If said guy is reading this, I think you and my gf would totally hit it off! =)
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
Warning: Unsanitary food handling! 

I saw the cashier touching the seaweed right after he touched the money without washing his hands. That was just so disgusting!!!

Sorry but I'm not coming back.
author: Vi N.

description:
Tried this place at SOMA food trucks during their Oscars Viewing Party. I knew I had to try it when I smelled the delicious broth from the table next to us - it got me drooling (and I wasn't even hungry at the time!)

We got the veggie ramen which has a choice of 3 toppings (tofu, corn, bamboo, cabbage, bean sprouts, and fungus). You also get half a soft boiled egg, green onions, and nori. We added garlic to the broth, which tasted delish. We paid extra for a whole egg - you can tell it had been marinating with sake and soy sauce. It was very flavorful and was cooked sliiightly over but still runny in the middle. 

The vegan miso broth was very tasty and wasn't too salty or oily. It's definitely different from a pork bone broth but that was good because that means it's less fatty.

My favorite part was the noodles. They're THICK - and I like my noodles thick. They were cooked perfectly so that it was chewy but not hard. Great to slurp up the soup with! 

The only gripe I have with this place is that it's a little pricey - our bowl was $15 after we chose 4 toppings and got an extra (half) egg. But I wouldn't hesitate to splurge again if I'm back in SOMA!
author: Venus F.

description:
It was my first time to this food truck. I picked up my order form and checked off what I wanted and gave it to the cashier. Please remember to include your name on the form because when there is a line, you won't know who's order is at the pickup window. Lucky for me I was the only one waiting and the line was behind me. It's all about luck and timing since it was lunchtime on Sunday. I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen which was thinly sliced pork (Chashu) and chicken soup base that has been boiled for 15 hours that comes with soft boiled egg, seaweed, fungus, bamboo, and green onions. I paid a $1.00 more for black garlic infused soup flavor. Hey, since I am down here at this food park, might as well splurge since things are going to be costly anyway. 

I really liked the flavor of the soup base, but I think it may be a little too much on salty side because I was a little thirsty after my meal. I can see and taste that the ingredients are fresh. I know there is room for improvement as time goes on, but overall it is a good truck. Yummy meal in my tummy. If my tummy is happy, then I am in complete zen. :-)
author: Priscilla L.

description: Just happened upon this place while making my way across town. There were a few folks outside eating and I'm a sucker for new ramen joints. Anyway, had the tonkatsu with kukuni and was disappointed. First, no black garlic was available. Second, the order took about 20 minutes. But my biggest issue was the broth. It has flavor, but not the deep milky flavor I was hoping for. I would say there was a lack of umami. The noodles were good and the staff was friendly. 2 stars feels right.
author: Jeremiah J.

description:
I absolutely love tonkotsu ramen so have to try any bowl which is easily accessible.  I'm not gonna travel to the peninsula to wait an hour or two for some strip mall ramen, but I'll totally get a tonkotsu bowl from a nearby food truck.  I often use Ippudo NY as my benchmark, since comparing to joints in Tokyo really isn't fair.  Theirs was just ok, hence the "A-OK" 3-star.

Tonkotsu Ramen w/ Kakuni, Black Garlic, Spicy: You pick your ramen, your garlic (black or fried) and your spicy level.  I went with second spiciest (basically the highest level where you don't have to pay extra).  That was probably a mistake.  Not because it was too spicy, but because it overpowered the flavor of the broth.  It tasted more like chalky chili powder than it did like tonkotsu.  Maybe the broth just wasn't that distinctive if it couldn't stand up to the chili powder?  The kakuni (pork belly) was nice; tender and heavily infused with 5-spice.  The noodles were decently chewy.  The bamboo shoots were a bit too chewy.  The seaweed was soggy from noodle steam after a quick walk home.  The half soft boiled egg was nice and creamy.
author: Adam B.

description:
This food truck was just what the doctor ordered. The fall weather snapped, the chilly wind is creeping in - and at an outdoor food truck park the only clear choice for me was #allthesoups. 

It took less than 10 minutes for my steaming bowl to be ready - my name was called out and I dug right in. I was impressed with the broth and noodles, all the veggies were delicious. The portion size was a little small for the price (about 15 dollars), but all and all I really enjoyed it. A pal hand the seafood option (his first ever time having Ramen!) and voted A-ok! 

You can add additional items to your soup as you like, and I definitely suggest you check YES for some fried or black garlic. It's good for your immune system folks, and its a must for the Tonkotsu option in my opinion. 

If this food truck was local to me, I'd be a regular for sure. Nab some asap if you see it around and the wind is howling - you'll feel full, happy and comforted in no time!!
author: Trish S.

description:
Torraku Ramen hit the spot on a cool October day. I had a hard time choosing which food truck I wanted at SoMa StrEat Food Park, but I am so glad that I decided on Torraku. The Tonkotsu Kakuni Ramen and Kakuni steamed bun were both filled with flavor.

To order you fill out a card with what you want in your ramen. There is a veggie ramen ordering sheet and a meat one. On the meat sheet there are five different broths to chose from, with your choice of either seafood, pork belly (Kakuni), or pork shoulder (Chashu) filling. You then check off your desired spiciness level and whether you want garlic or not. The bowls come with a soft boiled egg, green onions, seaweed, nori, bamboo shoots, and noodles. 

Based on recommendations from the staff I ordered the Tonkotsu Kakuni Ramen. I chose fried garlic and mild spice. I was debating between medium or mild, but was told the medium was pretty spicy so I stuck with mild. I am happy I did because it was the perfect amount of spice for me. The taste of the broth was amazing and was spiced well. The pork belly was flavorful and plentiful. The noodles were firm and tasty, and the egg added a perfect touch with yolk slightly running out of it. 

I added on the Kakuni steamed bun for a mere $2.50. I believe this a relatively new menu item, but they should definitely keep it on! The bun was light and soft, the pork belly was flavorful, and the sauce (not sure what it was) paired perfectly. 

I am so happy I chose Torraku Ramen out of all of my choices at the food truck park.
author: Kerry O.

description: Great ramen that's reasonably priced. Bowls are customizable, and extra meat is an option for not too much more. Gets busy on weekends and most weeknights.
author: Landon H.

description: I am hosting a bit of a cold and was craving a large bowl of tasty, hot ramen. This place hit the spot. I had the vegan ramen and tempura veggies. Broth was on point, tempura was crispy and tasty. Normally comes with shrimp but they were kind enough to modify. I must admit the multi order forms was a bit confusing. But I will get over it for this place. This is their third day open, smooth night with a good turn out. Welcome to the neighborhood  I will be back!
author: Nora C.

description: This is more of a fusion ramen, if you are looking for authentic ramen...there's better ramen in SF.  The noodles were too chewy and looks more yellow than regular ramen that we had in Japan and other spots in SF.  Tonkatsu broth is ok, the pork belly was nice and I enjoyed it.  If you want fusion ramen, this is ok... if you want authentic ramen, you will be better off somewhere else.
author: Xiuf L.

description: This is the best place to get ramen in San Francisco. The employees are so friendly and always accommodating to my diet/requests. Generally, Torraku offers at least one vegan option every day, but on Very Vegan Sunday they offer four. My absolute favorite is the vegan curry ramen, it is PHENOMENAL!!! The ramen comes with vegan fake meat and tofu, but I'm not a vegan who eats much of that stuff and I prefer veggies. Torraku has always been great about this and they always offer to add veggies in place of the fake meats / tofu, I generally add cabbage. Overall, the broth is thick and spiced well, the noodles are delicious, and the veggies are cooked perfectly. I could actually drink the broth all day and be happy. I love this place more than T's Tan Tan in Tokyo, it's soooooooo good.
author: Christina M.

description: I ordered the tonkatsu kakuni ramen and it was way too salty and garlicky.  If it had a little less salt and way less garlic, it would have been really good.  The portion was quite small (I got it delivered by Post Mates), especially considering the price (after tax it was over $16).  They were pretty generous with the pork belly though - two decent-sized slices in my order.  There are other places where you can get better ramen for a cheaper price, so I will not order from here again and would not recommend it.
author: Emma H.

description: My ramen had decent flavor but was not hot (barely warm). And we were with only customers there but no greeting or warmth or even mild welcome. And no service. And no follow up. I don't think they will make it unless the improve their service and attitude (And food temperature). But I hope they do, it would be great to have good ramen in this neighborhood. I will try it again in a month or two.
author: Sean Q.

description: Convenient, cheap, and really tasty ramen (the noodles are al dente, the tonkatsu broth is good to the last drop).
author: B. Y.

description: This is probably my favorite ramen place in San Francisco! The service is fast and friendly, and the miso ramen with pork belly is the best!
author: Evelyn B.

description: So glad that Potrero has a ramen option.  The ordering system needs to be revised as it was very confusing what to do with the slips of paper for a large party. Also, we had a group of 6 and one of our dishes came out a good 5 minutes later than everyone else's. Tighten up the operations and this business should build a solid customer base.
author: Chris T.

description: Ramen was good, ordered the tonkatsu with black garlic, crowded place hard to get a table. DON'T  stand by the door when it opens it closes hard and it could hit your back...it hurts!
author: S F.

description: This guys are great and friendly when you get there. The ramen was great in all sense, pretty much balanced and tasty.  i will recommend you to come and have a taste of their selection. Keep in mind that the parking is what you might look for.
author: Jonathan S.

description:
I have been back to Torraku about 3 times since my first visit. I love it! I've figured out my go-to order. It's the Tonkatsu Ramen with Chashu, medium spicy, and no garlic. It's my favorite in the city so far, and the price and portion size are very reasonable. It's perfect for SF weather. 

Parking is plentiful, metered but free most evenings and weekends. I like this Mission Bay food truck spot, but sometimes it gets crowded and a bunch of the seats/tables are reserved for private groups. It gets chilly too, so be prepared or try to find a spot inside a covered tent.
author: Veronica H.

description:
I recently started working in San Francisco, in an office building with no cafe, so I've been on the quest for awesome places that deliver.

At first I was a bit hesitant to order ramen since I thought it would be too messy to eat at work, or I thought the texture of the noodles would change, or temperature of the brother.  

However, Torraku has got it down to a science.  The broth comes separately, and is piping hot.  The other bowl with the ingredients, is loosely packed so your noodles don't get clumped up.  

When I poured the broth over the noodles, it was the perfect bowl of ramen!!!!  Extra hot, noodles were just the right amount of al dente and the spicy miso had a nice layer of fatty goodness on top that had me licking my lips the entire time.

Love the postmates delivery option and packaging.  They could earn the 6th star if they would deliver with the larger ramen spoons instead of the little plastic spoons since it's not very sexy to pick up my bowl at work to slurp up the goodness.  

Also a bowl is HUGE.  protip...next time I would probably save half for dinner, and just eat half at lunch..so I wouldn't pour all the soup in at once and would probably eat it in another bowl.
author: Vi Y.

description: Probably the best ramen i've had. I got the bone broth one with pork belly. The taste was freeekin delicious and presentation thumbs  Im definately going to be here often :) "say hello to your little friend". Clean and friendly service.
author: Jennifer T.

description: Ate here twice and the broth is not good.  It tastes strangely tart and sour.  Much better ramen to be had in this city.  The Pork belly was the best part.
author: Jay H.

description: So good and worth every penny!!! I've tried several types of their ramen and each time the pork is perfectly succulent and the broth is rich beyond belief. And the noodles, OMG, so good. They're the perfect texture and thickness and seasoned with some of their fried garlic... Ah! I must return soon. Highly recommended if you're in the area!
author: Quinn Li O.

description: Yum! Ordered the veggie ramen through Eat24 last night and it was delicious. The broth is very flavorful and good amount of toppings added and portion was a good size. My only note is that I ordered the 'mild' for spice level and it's a little spicy but I didn't mind. I will definitely be ordering again!
author: Ava M.

description: the vegan miso broth is pretty good here.  i came here tonight for a quick dinner, and the food comes out really fast.  i got the veggie ramen w/ an added egg, cabbage, bamboo and bean sprouts.  you get to choose whether you want fried garlic and the spice level of the broth.  i got spicy, and it was a good amount of spice w/o it being overwhelming.  there was no wait at all here, so it's a good spot to check out if you are in a hurry.
author: Helen T.

description: It's delicious!! Made with very high quality ingredients and also care from a great Japanese family!! Love it!:)
author: Ting L.

description:
If you're craving ramen but want to avoid the $16+/bowl price tags and 30-60 minute waits, I recommend Torraku Ramen.

I think that the ramen pretty good coming from a food truck. I myself ordered the miso ramen with cha shiu; I thought that my boyfriend's tonkatsu ramen with pork belly was far superior. 

Prices are fair - for $13~ flat you get a lot of noodles (I liked the noodles a lot), a few pieces of meat, half an egg, and a lot of flavor. I think it is a lot better than driving somewhere, struggling to find parking, waiting in a long line, and paying close to $20 for a bowl of ramen. I like Torraku for the convenience.
author: Mina K.

description:
Okok, pretty darn good for a food truck. Better than some REAL restaurants that serve ramen. 

Tried the curry one too and it was pretty darn satisfying! Definitely a go to spot in Mission Bay,
author: Christine M.

description:
I guess my timing was better than the first poster; I got there well after the lunchtime peak and waited for 10 minutes for mine. It was their first day of operation, so perhaps one should cut them some slack. So how was the ramen?

I liked my shoyu ramen with chashu just fine (though I'm not a ramen fanatic and therefore inexpert). It was piping hot, the medium curly noodles pleasantly chewy, and the broth deep in flavor and not overly salty. The (no cost) spicy option had the broth respectably spicy, so there's no need to order the "Extra Spicy" add-on unless you are a chili head. Not a lot of protein in the toppings, but hey, it's ramen.

I don't see a point in complaining about the price when you can see it up front before you order, though I am a little irritated when tax is added on, when most food trucks build it into the price. Double digit prices are, unfortunately, becoming the rule rather than the exception at new ramen joints.
author: Gary S.

description: Decent beef bowl, nothing special, almost reasonably priced at $9 pre-tax.
author: Inigo M.

description:
I am a ramen lover, had tried many ramen places in SF and finally got a chance to visit these the food trucks at Soma. Ordered their tonkatsu ramen, fast service, was surprised how big the pork slices were compared to other places where are even more expensive. Pork were very tendered and tasty, broth was flavorful and don't make your feel thirsty afterward. Noodles are chewy in the way I like. 
And their pork belly bun is absolutely a Must try! 
Will definitely come back!
author: Zoe W.

description: i've eaten here many times, i always mark spicy, and extra noodles, every time i've eaten here i leave full. DRINK THE SOUP!!
author: Hiki L.

description: I got the veggie ramen.. It was okay, I appreciated how they bagged the broth and noodles in two different containers. Would I crave it again? I am not sure, the broth needed a little something something
author: Ale B.

description: We had the vegan ramen. I'm usually disappointed, but not this time. My kids, total carnivores, devoured the ramen. I will definitely return
author: Jenny N.

description: Very good ramen for a food truck! The soup has a distinct taste to it and I don't know if it's because I know it's made from organic pork and chicken...or what. Hah, no I didn't know it was organic until after I ate my ramen. When I found out it was organic, that's when I came to a conclusion that that is why it tasted different. I ordered the pork belly black garlic tonkotsu. They have the best pork belly! It was so soft that it broke when I picked it up with my chopsticks. I also added corn but it comes with half soft boiled egg, green onions, seaweed, fungus, bamboo shoots, and nori. Everything was perfect. Not too salty and a pretty big portion for a bowl of ramen. I couldn't finish my ramen and I shared with my boyfriend. I will be back!
author: Joey C.

description:
Wow. One of the worst dining experiences ever. Let's start with the main event--the food. I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen. While the noodles had a nice bite, the broth was thin (for tonkotsu) and had an odd, off flavor, like Chinese 5-spice, or star anise, which is totally NOT a Japanese flavor. The chashu was good, but as I ate the ramen, the noodles got very soggy. My dining partner ordered the Chicken Katsudon, which also had an off flavor, due to the katsu sauce. The chicken was tasteless and was not breaded with Panko, more like normal breadcrumbs, which added to the off flavors. We also split an order of gyoza, which were deep fried, not pan fried, as was shown on their menu. Totally disappointing. 

Let's move on to the overall dining experience. The ordering system is totally lame. You have to fill out a little form, checking off what sort of ramen or donburi you want, the level of spiciness, and whatever extras you want. There's nothing to write on, so you have to step out of line to go to the counter or a table to fill this out. And since you're bending down filling out this form, you don't notice the huge menu that's posted on the wall behind you. When you get to the cashier, they review the entire form with you as they enter your order on the iPad. Why make us go through all the trouble of filling out a form when you're going to make us go through it again at the cashier? And why don't you move your huge menu behind the cashier so that you can see it as you walk in? Once you get to the cashier, you notice the beverage cooler hidden in the corner, which turns the space into a bottleneck. 

They've done nothing to the space, other than paint it a hideous red and black. It doesn't feel clean. There are a couple of ceiling fans from the restaurant's previous incarnations, and I don't think they've ever been cleaned. The grease and grime are obvious. And the service was terrible. The guys at the cash register were nice enough, but the woman who brought out the food couldn't have cared less. 

With so many decent and great ramen places in SF, this one can be avoided.
author: Kent T.

description:
Pretty decent shoyu ramen. The pork belly is delicious and I am giving it 4 stars cuz the gluten free noodles were delicious.

The negative of this place was the portion size - a lot of broth but light on the noodles.

It's also really expensive -$15 a bowl. Man, SF food trucks are crazy expensive.
author: Madison W.

description: This place is obviously run by amateurs.  When I went there, it was cold outside, yet they had the door open, and you couldn't close it, so the place was freezing.  I ordered chicken katzu.  Several people who placed their order after me were served first.  The dish was cold when it arrived, indicating it sat in the window for a while before it was delivered.  Once I tried it, I knew I would never return to this horrible place.  They gave the impression they didn't about Caucasian customers.  They won't last a year.  BTW, I wouldn't return there even if the offered to pay for the meal.  Don't waste your time trying the horrible place.
author: Harold S.

description:
I got the spicy garlic vegan ramen and it was AWESOME. So flavorful and fresh, nice size portion (although I scarfed it down so quick), noodles were yummy, and any garlic fan will be in heaven. 

Decided to order from here on a whihm, I didn't have super high expectations from a mostly non-veg ramen place, but I'm happy to say I was very pleasantly surprised!  Some of the best vegan ramen I've ever had. YUM!
author: Julie G.

description:
in my experience, Torraku Ramen is the first to serve ramen via a food truck in the bay area. many options of ramen available, choose Tonkotsu chashu with med. spiciness and garlicky.

locale: SF soma street park(2/8/16)

eats: tonkotsu chashu, etc (12+tax)
-first tasting of broth hinted a mistake in ordering spiciness, no tonkotsu flavor came thru,
tonkotsu flavor too faint.
-"chashu" just lean pork, not chashu at all.
-1/2 egg was hard boiled and looked more like an tea egg, brownish in pigmentation, soy sauce flavored
-bamboo, seaweed, chewy noodles rounded out the experience
-everything tasted "fresh", though not authentic, some msg may be present,
2.5 stars for inauthencity, lack of value..

temaki:
-ramen came out in 5 minutes
-server was concerned whether i was eating it right away. told him "yes"
i know ramen doesn't keep long. sogginess a possible dilemma.
author: Victor G.

description: Surpringly good ramen coming out of a food truck. I really enjoyed the black garlic and fall apart pork belly. The miso ramen broth was very rich and flavorful. Medium spiciness was just right. The people working were really nice and still took my order as they were preparing to close.
author: Kevin B.

description: Honestly, this place is really good considering it being a food truck as opposed to a typical ramen restaurant. You don't have to wait in a line for hours just get seated and that was another big attraction. I loved how you get to build your ramen bowl to how you like it and you don't have to worry about them messing up your order either. The egg was cooked perfectly and the noodles were ridiculously good too. Love how spicy the black garlic broth was and finally how lean the meat they used was. Highly recommend this place to anyone who goes out of their way to find lit ramen places. The price was under $15 for crazy good ramen.
author: Jayoolian G.

description: it's pretty good! broth is great. NO MSG is a must and much appreciated. The noodle was more cooked than I liked it...could improve on the texture...tasted like the instant kind... nice to have this option near work!
author: Xiu L.

description:
I'm visiting San Fran for the first time.  After making my way through the homeless tent gauntlet I came over to Soma and tried Torraku Ramen.  

I ordered the Shoyu Ramen and added Kimchi. The service was good, my food came relatively quick.
author: Ray V.

description: I have to say, this food truck is better than some of the sit down ramen  restaurants I've been to in the Bay Area. It's pretty pricey for being a food truck ramen joint, but I'm not mad. They have pork belly as an alternative pork meat option and you can add other veggies or items to your ramen to customize it--but beware--it will get expensive. Enjoyed it enough to go back for more. Pretty content but still searching for that PERFECT ramen spot.
author: Hana D.

description:
The place seems relatively new but the Customer service was excellent. Pretty boy helped me pick my order of tonkatsu. The noodle soup was on point, hella meat but the soup was a little salty. Definitely coming back again though. #torrakuramen #comeforlunch #comefordinner
#bringyourself #bringyourentirefamily #heckbringyourfriendsentirefamily
author: Jay D.

description: Good Ramen! The Buns are delicious! And the soup is so good! Highly recommended. We will definitely go back and eat again.
author: Mandy L.

description:
Torraku Ramen is amazing!!!

I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen with Chashu with Kakuni added, and it was delicious.

The broth was scrumptiously and beautifully prepared with top notch ingredients.
I added aged black garlic to this gourmet bowl of noodles which enhanced the flavor.

Noodles, meat, veggies, soup base were all perfect.

It's damn near hard to find a ramen place in the bay area this good without having to wait 2 hours to be seated.

Will definitely come back again!!
author: Thomas N.

description: I had Tonkotsu Kakuni Ramen here. I would say it taste pretty good for food truck. When the place get crowded, it will be hard to find a place to sit but ramen it self was very good! If they open a restaurant I will definitely go more often.
author: Zach Q.

description:
Was majorly craving ramen this morning and Torraku was the closest and also open. Always down to vary my selection of ramen in sf, especially for a midweek brunch. 

But unfortunately I have to give their bowl of ramen a 1/5 rating due to presentation and flavor. Not only did my tonkotsu broth not taste homemade, but it was so salty and cloacked by a thick layer of oil I could barely finish half the serving. 

Toppings came sinking in the bowl and it really just seemed like no mind was paid to how they were layered in. Today's experience tasted like an instant bowl of ramen. And at a price point of $13.05, I'm going to really have to eliminate this spot in my ramen catalog all together.
author: Sloane T.

description: Great addition to Spark! It's always hard to find vegan ramen as generally the noodles have egg or the broth is meat based. Torraku clearly labels their broths vegetarian and vegan and they are very knowledgeable about ingredients. This is one of the best veggie broths that I've tasted. Fresh veggies, real ramen noodles, and a broth that overall has a great flavor and is not overly salty. I hope they are at Spark permanently as I'll definitely be back.
author: Sarah S.

description:
Super slow to order and make ramen. And way overpriced. Tax is not included. Spent about 40 minutes to get my ramen after ordering.

Edit: owner contacted me and explained that they just opened and are still getting into the flow of things. I'll try it again in the future and see if it's improved
author: Geobio B.

description:
Honestly, the best ramen I've had. And I've tried a couple spots around SF and the east bay. To be fair, I have yet to venture to the South Bay, BUT, as it stands, this place is sooooooo gooooodddd. I always get the miso, with fried garlic, and medium spice and KAKUNI. The pork belly is unrealllll. It falls apart in your mouth, adds such a rich piggy flavor to the soup. I cry everytime I get it. And the people who run this truck are SUPER nice and honestly care so much about their food. It shows. 

A million stars, best place to get ramen, just shut up and give them your money.
author: E S.

description: Best ramen! My boyfriend and I stopped here on our road trip down from Portland & it was the best little dinner to enjoy with our pitcher of sangria that we got from another truck there. Can't wait to go back!
author: Sabrina A.

description: Excellent quality soup, noodles and ingredients. A little pricey but worth it for the quick convenience. Try the curry ramen, very tasty!
author: Alex R.

description: veggie ramen with fried garlic, medium spicy! my favorite sunday meal. we live pretty close to the soma streat park (thankfully) it's been our go to during nba playoffs and will continue to be for any sports since we opted out of getting cable when we moved here (but some things you just cant miss, right?) anyways. RAMENNNNN. the perfect spice for me. the chili oil can get a bit heavy on some days but honestly its never been a reason for me to complain or be dissatisfied. i get corn, tofu, fungi & bean sprouts. this definitely competes with our previous favorite ramen spot in houston,tx. keep it up guys, we'll see you next sunday!
author: Taylor N.

description: I give 5 stars because the softboiled eggs were done exactly how I like them, the ramen noodles are great , broth has great flavors, and they are really the kind of authentic ramen I look for. I ordered through yelp and it was difficult to get my order I ended up waiting an extra 15 minutes even though my food was ready because they didn't call my name. But it was still worth it for the ramen flavors I crave
author: Alex T.

description: I got the garlic miso veggie ramen with corn, bean sprouts, and tofu but there are many options to choose from. The noodles are excellent, the egg was cooked perfectly, and the mild broth still had a nice spice to it. A single order is definitely enough for 2 meals, and the container comes with a cover so you can store leftovers in the fridge. Pretty damn good for $13!
author: Joni B.

description: I work near here and have had their ramen a few times already.  The first time was a challenge as the wait time was around 25-30minutes.  Since then, they have way improved, wait time is now around 10min. For a food truck, the tonkotsu ramen with kakuni (pork belly) is actually pretty darn good.  I'm really happy this is so close and I can come here for lunch whenever they're available.
author: ML ..

description: One of a kind ramen and awesome customer service! Especially Benny who gives great suggestions!!!
author: Carolyn M.

description: I ordered the Miso Ramen and it was pretty good. The atmosphere at the "Food Park" is kind of nice if the weather is cooperating. I need to try the rest of the menu now...
author: Cris B.

description: I'll admit that I wasn't expecting much from a ramen food truck, but this place definitely exceeded my expectations! The staff is very friendly and, while a tad bit steeper in price than its competitors, it's worth every dollar!  I'd highly recommend getting both the chashu and Kakuni with extra egg, no matter which one you choose!  Also, definitely get the black garlic too!
author: Chris C.
